awd_titl_txt: CC* Compute: A high-performance computing cluster to accelerate research, education, and training at Rhodes College
awd_abstract_narration:
Rhodes College is building and deploying a high-performance computing cluster that serves as the cornerstone of a campus-wide research computing center. This project establishes a needed computing resource that enables new capabilities for researchers and students in computer science, biology, mathematics, chemistry, and economics. The cluster provides a new computing resource at a scale not previously available on campus and advances the institutions' ability to support research, including analyzing mitochondrial DNA, modeling inorganic compounds, and improving the performance and usability of parallel and distributed systems. As a research-intensive liberal arts college, this cluster system at Rhodes College dramatically advances the opportunities for students to be engaged in computation-based scientific research alongside researchers in a wide range of disciplines. This cluster system also functions as a platform for classroom experiences that help students understand how computational methods can be used to better understand the world. The system supports class activities in computer science, biology, and mathematics. Additionally, this project enables researchers to prepare their experiments to run on national compute resources through XSEDE and will also contribute unused computing resources to the Open Science Grid, a national, distributed computing partnership.

The cluster system supports both high-performance and high-throughput workloads with an overall system capacity of 1,584 cores, 9TB of memory, and 504 TB of storage. The cluster is comprised of a login server, storage server, 44 compute nodes, and a 100Gbit/s InfiniBand interconnect network.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award funded a new high-performance computing cluster that provides a modern, campus-wide research computing environment at Rhodes College, a selective liberal arts college located in Memphis, TN. This equipment underpins a newly formed Academic Computing Center at Rhodes -- a centralized computing resource for both research and classroom use. The purchased cluster was acquired from Penguin Computing and is a 2,112 node AMD-based distributed memory system with a Mellanox Infiniband interconnect. The system provides users with a total of 11.2TB of memory and 504TB of storage overall.

This system currently in use by researchers working cutting-edge projects in areas such as computer science, biology, chemistry, and physics. The cluster has been used to publish novel techniques for load-balancing parallel programs in computer science. The cluster is currently also being used for developing new algorithms for genetic analysis, chemistry simulations that model electronic structure of materials, along with other research projects in progress.


The system has also been used as a teaching tool, both as a tool in the classroom, but also as an means for undergraduates to be involved with the setup and operation of a modern high-performance computing system. Given the large enrollments in our biology and computer science programs, this cluster has also provided new opportunities to broaden participation in the sciences. Several of our NSF S-STEM supported students have used this system as a research tool and also in the classroom.  In addition to traditional research and classroom use, Rhodes has been able to hire new faculty in both biology and chemistry from underrepresented groups that use computational methods in their research programs, demonstrating its value to recruit and retain an excellent and diverse faculty. Lastly, the cluster provides computing cycles to the Open Science Grid, a national consortium for distributed high-thoughput computing.
